channel.title: Gateway to ideas
channel.description:
This discussion series, produced by the American Library Association, features noted authors, critics and scholars on various topics.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: The U.S. and Western alliance
item.description: The U.S. and the Western Alliance. Moderator: Quincy Howe, editor, Atlas magazine. Prof. Richard Lowenthal, Free U. of Berlin and author, "World Communism"; Prof. William T.R. Fox, Columbia U.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: #8: Should We Be Educating For Excellence
Are the arts becoming incomprehensible
item.description: Are the Arts Becoming Incomprehensible? Moderator: Anne Fremantle. Harold Rosenberg, critic, author of "The Anxious Object"; Claude Marks (or Marx), author.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: The U.S. and the Far East
item.description: The U.S. and the Far East. Moderator: Quincy Howe, editor, Atlas magazine. O. Edmond Club, Columbia U., author of "Twentieth Century China"
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: The job of the presidency
item.description: The Job of the Presidency. Moderator: Quincy Howe, editor, Atlas magazine. Dr. Louis Koenig, New York U., author, "The Chief Executive," and Dr. Charles Masterson, exec dir National Safety Council
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Books into mass media
item.description: Books Into Mass Media. Moderator: Leo Rosten, senior editor, Look magazine. Horace Alpert, film critic, Saturday Review.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: #18 "Africa: Past, Present, and Future" with Quincy Howe
#3: Wanted: A Redefinition of the Classics
Wanted: Redefinition of classics
item.description: This program presents a discussion on redefining the classics. Panelists are Elizabeth Hardwick, co-founder of New York Review of Books; and Steven Marcus, Columbia University.
item.dc:creator: Meyer, Eva
item.dc:subject: Radio panel discussions

item.title: The changing role of magazines
item.description: The Changing Role of Magazines. Moderator: Leonard Robinson, Columbia U. Geraldine Rhodes, exec. editor, McCall's; Ralph Backland, managing editor, Horizon magazine
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: #19 "The US and the Western Alliance" with Quincy Howe
Shifting role of the university
item.description: This program explores the role of the university in modern American society. The moderator is Dr. Harold Taylor. Guests are: Dr. Charles Frankel; and Professor Daniel Bell, both of Columbia University.
item.dc:creator: Meyer, Eva
item.dc:subject: Radio panel discussions

item.title: Who sets standards and values?
item.description: Who Sets Standards and Values? Harding Lemay, publishing executive; Dr. Terence Hopkins, Columbia U. Moderator: Virginia Peterson.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: #14: The U.S. and the Far East
Present-day immigration waves
item.description: Present-Day Immigration Waves. Moderator: Leo Rosten, senior editor, Look magazine. Pietro DeDonato, novelist; Dr. Seymour Yelland, New York U.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Education and social change
item.description: This program focuses on the links between education and social change. The moderator is Dr. Harold Taylor. Guests are Dr. Margaret Mead, anthropologist; and Dr. Melvin Tumin, Princeton University.
item.dc:creator: Meyer, Eva
item.dc:subject: Radio panel discussions

item.title: Protestant ethic today
item.description: This program discusses the Protestant ethic in the twentieth century. The moderator is Dr. Benjamin Nelson of SUNY Stony Brook. Panelists are Professor James M. Gustafson, Yale University; and Professor Thomas F. O'Day, Columbia University.
item.dc:creator: Meyer, Eva
item.dc:subject: Radio panel discussions

item.title: Africa: Past, present and future
item.description: Africa: Past, Present and Future. Moderator: Quincy Howe, editor, Atlas magazine. George Loft, sr vice president, African American Institute; George Houser, a founder of Congress of Racial Equality (CORE)
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Freud and twentieth century literature
item.description: Freud and 20th Century Literature. Dr. Benjamin Nelson, SUNY Stony Brook and editor of Freud and the 20th Century; Dr. Philip Weissman of New York Psychoanalytic Society. Moderator: Virginia Peterson.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Can attitudes be legislated?
item.description: Can Attitudes be Legislated? Leo Rosten, senior editor, Look magazine, moderates. Dr. Howard Zinn, Boston U., author of "The Southern Mystique"
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Each to the other
item.description: Each to the Other. A discussion of the cross-fertilization of French and American literature. Maria Jolas, Ira Morris. Moderator: Anne Fremantle.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Is science sterilizing humanistic thought?
item.description: This program asks the question of the extent to which science has changed the way humanity thinks. The guest is I.I. Robbie, Columbia University.
item.dc:creator: Meyer, Eva
item.dc:subject: Radio panel discussions

item.title: Will man be modified?
item.description: This program explores how humans will evolve in the ever-changing environment. The discussion is moderated by L.U. Bell, science editor, New York Herald Tribune. Guests are Dr. Ruth Sager, Columbia University; and Amran Scheinfeld, author, "Your Heredity and Environment."
item.dc:creator: Meyer, Eva
item.dc:subject: Radio panel discussions

item.title: What makes a good biography
item.description: what Makes a Good Biography? Moderator: Anne Fremantle. Leon Edel, Pulitzer Prize winning author; Prof. James Gifford, Columbia U.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Let's redefine tolerance
item.description: Let's Redefine Tolerance. Features Daniel Patrick Moynihan, co-author of Beyond the Melting Pot. Moderator: Anne Fremantle.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: American genius for self-examination
item.description: The American Genius for Self-Examination. Alan Pryce-Jones of New York Herald Tribune and Russell Lynes of Harper's.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Labor, leisure and automation
item.description: Labor Leisure and Automation. Leo Perlis of AFL-CIO; Edward T. Chase, author and vice president, Cunningham and Walsh
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Spiritual poverty
item.description: Spiritual Poverty. Moderator: Leo Rosten, senior editor, Look magazine. Bill Hubbard, 17 year old Columbia U. student who produced play based on "A Man of All Work," and Rev. William S. Van Meter
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Should we educate for excellence?
item.description: Should We Educate for Excellence? Dr. Abraham Tannenbaum, Yeshiva U.; Dr. Harold Whiteman, New York U. Moderator: Virginia Peterson.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Books that formed my opinions
item.description: Books that Formed my Opinions. Rep. John Lindsay of New York; Leon Edel, Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award Winner for his biography of Henry James.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.

item.title: Changing attitudes toward women
item.description: Changing Attitudes Toward Women. Margaret Cousins, Doubleday and Co.; Morton Hunt, author. Moderator: Virginia Peterson.
item.dc:creator: American Library Association
item.dc:subject: Books and reading--United States.
